verses.text: The righteous man perishes, and no one takes it to heart; generous men are taken away, while no one understands that the righteous are taken away from calamity.
verses.comment: The text highlights the mystery of why righteous people sometimes die early, suggesting it is a deliverance from coming evil. This foreshadows the Christian understanding of suffering and death as a passage to peace for the just (cf. Phil. 1:21-23).

verses.text: They enter into peace; those who walk uprightly rest in their beds.
verses.comment: There is a deep implication of rest and peace for the righteous after death. This is in line with the hope in an afterlife and the communion of saints. Early Christian liturgy echoed this verse when praying for the faithful departed.

verses.text: But you, draw near, sons of the sorceress, offspring of the adulterer and prostitute.
verses.comment: Those called 'sons of the sorceress' represent people who have strayed from God's law, participating in spiritual 'adultery.' Jesus often confronted such hypocrisy (see John 8:44).

verses.text: Whom are you mocking? Against whom do you open your mouth wide and stick out your tongue? Are you not children of rebellion, offspring of deceit?
verses.comment: Isaiah challenges the rebellious to consider their actions, especially those who outwardly scorn God’s commands—a reminder of Jesus' words against those who outwardly observe religion but inwardly are far from God (Matt. 15:7-9).

verses.text: You burn with lust among the oaks, under every green tree, you slaughter your children in the valleys, under the clefts of the rocks.
verses.comment: Isaiah exposes pagan practices, including sacrifices and rituals connected to fertility cults. Such actions were explicitly condemned by the Law, showing Israel’s covenant betrayal.

verses.text: Among the smooth stones of the valley is your portion; they, they are your lot; even to them you have poured out drink offerings and brought grain offerings. Shall I be appeased for these things?
verses.comment: The 'smooth stones' likely refer to idols used in pagan rituals. Isaiah points out the futility of idol worship compared with the proper worship established by God. Authentic worship is done according to God's instruction.

verses.text: On a high and lofty mountain you have set your bed, and there you went up to offer sacrifice.
verses.comment: High places were associated with idolatrous worship contrary to the Temple worship. The 'bed' imagery refers to spiritual unfaithfulness, a theme Christ later addresses when He calls for worship 'in spirit and truth' (John 4:23-24).

verses.text: Behind the door and the doorpost you have set up your memorial; for, far from Me, you have uncovered your bed, climbed into it, and made it wide, and made a covenant with them. You loved their bed, and you saw their nakedness.
verses.comment: The passage uses marriage symbolism to show Israel’s covenant-breaking. The hidden nature (‘behind the door’) reflects a double life, contrasting the call to open faithfulness. The spiritual meaning points to the dangers of divided loyalties.

verses.text: You went to the king with oil, and multiplied your perfumes; you sent your envoys far away, and made yourselves low, even to Sheol.
verses.comment: The 'king' may refer to a foreign ruler or a false god. Israel's political alliances are pictured as unfaithfulness, pointing to the concept that true safety comes from faith in God alone.

verses.text: You were wearied by your many ways, yet you did not say, 'It is hopeless.' You found renewed strength, so you did not faint.
verses.comment: Even in spiritual exhaustion, stubbornness persists. This speaks to the persistent but misguided human desire to seek fulfillment apart from God—a warning echoed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Whom did you dread and fear, so that you lied, and did not remember Me, nor take it to heart? Have I not kept silent, even for a long time, so you do not fear Me?
verses.comment: God’s patience is often misread as indifference. The silence of God tests whether faith is genuine or only circumstantial. This resonates with Christ's warnings about hypocrisy.

verses.text: I will declare your righteousness and your works, but they will not profit you.
verses.comment: External displays of piety without sincere faith or repentance are empty. The New Testament repeatedly emphasizes that faith, working through love, justifies (cf. Gal. 5:6).

verses.text: When you cry out, let your collection of idols deliver you! The wind will carry them all off, a breath will take them away. But whoever takes refuge in Me shall inherit the land and possess My holy mountain.
verses.comment: Idols are powerless compared to the Lord. The promise of inheriting the 'holy mountain' echoes throughout Scripture, ultimately fulfilled in the life to come and in worshiping God through the one Church.

verses.text: And it will be said, 'Build up, build up, prepare the way, remove every obstacle from the way of My people.'
verses.comment: The call to 'prepare the way' connects with John the Baptist's ministry and Christ’s coming. It also spiritually points to removing barriers to full communion with God and His people.

verses.text: For thus says the One who is high and lifted up, who inhabits eternity, whose name is Holy: 'I dwell in the high and holy place, but also with the one who is contrite and lowly in spirit, to revive the spirit of the lowly and to revive the heart of the contrite.'
verses.comment: This verse powerfully reveals God’s transcendence and His loving presence with the humble. It forms the basis of the Christian understanding of humility and contrition as conditions for receiving grace, seen in many acts of repentance and confession.

verses.text: 'For I will not contend forever, nor will I always be angry; for the spirit would grow faint before Me, the breath of life that I made.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy limits His righteous anger. Divine discipline is always ordered toward restoration, not destruction. This lays a foundation for the enduring hope of reconciliation.

verses.text: 'Because of the iniquity of his unjust gain I was angry, I struck him; I hid My face and was angry, but he kept turning away in the way of his own heart.'
verses.comment: Persistent sin hardens the heart; yet God’s judgment is meant to lead sinners back to repentance rather than utter ruin, paralleling Christ’s call to ongoing conversion.

verses.text: 'I have seen his ways, but I will heal him; I will lead him and restore comfort to him and to his mourners,'
verses.comment: God’s promise of healing and comfort for repentant sinners shows His fatherly love. This anticipates Christ’s ministry as healer and restorer of broken hearts.

verses.text: 'Peace, peace, to the far and to the near,' says the Lord, 'and I will heal him.'
verses.comment: This universal promise of peace echoes the message brought by Christ, who reconciles those far and near. The restoration of Israel is also seen as fulfilled in the gathering of all peoples into a unified family of faith.

verses.text: But the wicked are like the tossing sea, for it cannot be quiet, and its waters toss up mire and dirt.
verses.comment: The unrest of the wicked contrasts with the promised peace for the righteous. Sin brings disturbance to the soul, while God brings stillness and order.

verses.text: 'There is no peace,' says my God, 'for the wicked.'
verses.comment: This somber statement is both a warning and an invitation—to seek the true peace that only God can provide. The ultimate fulfillment comes in the peace Christ offers those who abide in Him (John 14:27).
